concept.initial_blurb: Think about your Mythos. In the legend, was your Mythos responsible for a major change in the world around her? Was she able to control an element or even create it out of thin air? Was she a great warrior or somehow able to influence others? How did she do that?
concept.question: What change does your Mythos wish to effect in the world?

A.question: What is the most common way you use your Mythos to affect the world?

B.question: What useful reverse effect can you exert?

C.question: What useful quality does your main effect have?

example_answers: better in damp conditions, the more the merrier, feeds off fear, back-to-back fighting.

example_answers: reduce buildings to rubbles, good for abducting children, easily manipulates metals, "you can run but you can't hide"

example_answers: blow freezing cold -> encase someone in ice
celestial martial arts -> falling star roundhouse kick
F.question: What special variants or specific uses of your Mythos' main form of expression have you mastered?

G.question: What additional expression, not necessarily related to the main one, does your Mythos have?

example_answers: selectively hit targets in an area
H.question: What trick shots or special maneuvers can you do with your expression powers?

I.question: What attitude to you adopt when expressing your Mythos?

J.question: How can you use your power to shield yourself, especially from similar effects?

example_answers: One of them once witnessed you expressing your Mythos at full power. Ask them what they thought about it. If it scared them, take a Hurt point on them. If they appreciated it, take a Help point on them.
You feel like one of them wants you to hold back and refrain from expressing your Mythos. Ask them what is their reason. Take a Hurt point on them.

To your Mythos, one of them seems like the modern-day version of a character in its legend. If they were your foe in the legend, take a Hurt point on them. If they were your ally or loved one, or if you were their rescuer, take a Help point on them.
(Pied Piper of Hamelin) Play Them Like A Flute

only effective against a single opponent
